The following is a '''list of unproduced [[Darren Aronofsky]] projects''' in roughly chronological order. During his long career, American film director Darren Aronofsky has worked on a number of projects which never progressed beyond the pre-production stage under his direction. Some of these projects fell in [[development hell]] or were cancelled.
== 1990s == === ''Ronin'' === Eleven days after the release of ''[[Pi (film)|Pi]]'', his first film, Aronofsky signed a deal with [[New Line Cinema]] in July 1998 to direct a film adaptation of [[Frank Miller (comics)|Frank Miller]]'s ''[[Ronin (DC Comics)|Ronin]]'' comic book series.<ref>{{cite web|author=Benedict Carver,Dan Cox |url=https://variety.com/1998/film/news/aronofsky-draws-on-comic-1117478663/ |title=Aronofsky draws on comic |publisher=Variety |date=1998-07-21 |accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> [[Frank Miller (comics)|Frank Miller]], the author of the comic book, was attached to write the script.<ref>{{cite web|last=Linder |first=Brian |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2000/10/16/the-bat-men-speak |title=The Bat-Men Speak |publisher=IGN |date=2000-10-16 |accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> However, the project never materialized and Aronofsky left it to direct ''[[Requiem for a Dream]]''.
== 2000s == === ''Sector 7'' === On May 24, 2000, Aronofsky was announced to direct a film adaptation of [[David Wiesner]]'s ''[[Sector 7#Film adaptation|Sector 7]]'' for [[Nickelodeon Movies]]. Eric Watson was attached to produce the film. However, the project finally fell into [[development hell]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.corona.bc.ca/films/details/sector7.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20010410070243/http://www.corona.bc.ca/films/details/sector7.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2001-04-10 |title=Coming Attractions |date= |accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> and Aronofsky moved to other projects.
=== ''Batman: Year One'' === On September 21, 2000, ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' reported that Aronofsky had signed a deal with [[Warner Bros.]] to direct a fifth [[Batman]] film based on [[Frank Miller (comics)|Frank Miller]]'s acclaimed comic book ''[[Batman: Year One]]'', with Miller attached to write the script, with Eric Watson attached to produce and with Aronofsky's frequent collaborator [[Matthew Libatique]] to work on it.<ref>{{cite web|author=Dana Harris |url=https://variety.com/2000/film/news/wb-sends-pi-guy-into-the-bat-cave-1117786714/ |title=WB sends ‘Pi’ guy into the Bat Cave |publisher=Variety |date=2000-09-21 |accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Andrew O. Thompson |url=https://variety.com/2000/film/news/matthew-libatique-1117788894/ |title=Matthew Libatique |publisher=Variety |date=2000-11-07 |accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> The film was intended to be a [[reboot (fiction)|reboot]] of the [[Batman (1989 film series)|film series]],<ref name="autogenerated2000">{{cite web|last=Linder |first=Brian |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2000/12/06/aronofsky-talks-batman-year-oneagain |title=Aronofsky Talks Batman: Year One...Again |publisher=IGN |date=2000-12-06 |accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> after the failure of ''[[Batman & Robin (film)|Batman & Robin]]'' in 1997, although [[Warner Bros.]] originally planned to release the film as a prequel of [[Tim Burton]]'s ''[[Batman (1989 film)|Batman]]''.<ref name="autogenerated2000"/> [[Christian Bale]], who later portrayed [[Batman]] in [[Christopher Nolan]]'s ''[[The Dark Knight Trilogy]]'' was attached to star in the lead role.<ref>{{cite news|author= Adam Smith|title= The Original ''American Psycho''|work= [[Empire (magazine)|Empire]]|date= July 2005|pages= 74–80, 82, 84, 87}}</ref> [[Gillian B. Loeb]] was supposed to be the main antagonist of the film, replacing [[Carmine Falcone]] as the head of [[Gotham City]]'s mafia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://leonscripts.users5.50megs.com/scripts/BATMANYEARONEscript.htm |title=BATMAN YEAR ONE By Frank Miller |website=Leonscripts.users5.50megs.com |date= |accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> Aronofsky also planned to film the movie in [[Ciudad Vieja, Montevideo]], [[Uruguay]].<ref>{{cite web|last=McKnight |first=Brent |url=http://www.cinemablend.com/new/Why-Darren-Aronofsky-Batman-Movie-Never-Happened-According-Frank-Miller-116237.html |title=Why Darren Aronofsky's Batman Movie Never Happened, According To Frank Miller |publisher=Cinemablend |date=2016-03-04 |accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> However, on June 30, 2002, Aronofsky and Miller finally left the project due to other commitments.<ref>{{cite web|author=Dana Harris |url=https://variety.com/2002/film/news/wb-fewer-pix-more-punch-1117869140/ |title=WB: fewer pix, more punch |publisher=Variety |date=2002-06-30 |accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> A [[Reboot (fiction)|reboot]] of the [[Batman (1989 film series)|''Batman'' film series]] was finally released in 2005 as ''[[Batman Begins]]'' and directed by [[Christopher Nolan]].
=== ''Flicker'' === On January 28, 2003, Aronofsky was reported to direct a film adaptation of [[Theodore Roszak (scholar)|Theodore Roszak]]'s [[Flicker (novel)#Film adaptation|novel ''Flicker'']].<ref>{{cite web|author=Dana Harris |url=https://variety.com/2003/film/markets-festivals/regency-new-home-for-pi-guy-1117879646/ |title=Regency new home for ‘Pi’ guy |publisher=Variety |date=2003-01-28 |accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.filmcomment.com/article/unproduced-and-unfinished-films-a-ongoing-film-comment-project/ |title=Unproduced and Unfinished Films: An Ongoing Film Comment project |publisher=Film Comment |date=2015-04-07 |accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> ''[[Fight Club]]'' [[screenwriter]] [[Jim Uhls]] was attached to write the script.<ref>{{cite web|author=Dana Harris |url=https://variety.com/2003/film/markets-festivals/hard-time-for-fight-duo-1117892678/ |title=‘Hard’ time for ‘Fight’ duo |publisher=Variety |date=2003-09-18 |accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> However, on February 15, 2006, ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' reported that Aronofsky left the project and moved to [[Universal Studios]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Gabriel Snyder |url=https://variety.com/2006/film/features/pi-guy-getting-into-u-1117938319/ |title=‘Pi’ guy getting into U |publisher=Variety |date=2006-02-15 |accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref>
=== ''Watchmen'' === In July 2004, Aronofsky was hired by [[Paramount Pictures]] to direct a [[Watchmen (film)|film adaptation of ''Watchmen'']], with [[David Hayter]] as writer (who wrote the script in October 2001)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/movies |title=Movie Reviews, Trailers, Interviews, Wikis & Posters for Movies |publisher=IGN |date= |accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> and with [[Lawrence Gordon (producer)|Lawrence Gordon]], [[Lloyd Levin]] and Eric Watson as producers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/thr/film/brief_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1000584187 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060105145306/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/thr/film/brief_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1000584187 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2006-01-05 |title=Hollywoodreporter.com |date= |accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> However, at the end, Aronofsky left the project due to scheduling contracts with ''[[The Fountain]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/thr/film/brief_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1000724534 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2006-09-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5mqgGAdta?url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/thr/film/brief_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1000724534 |archivedate=2010-01-17 |df= }}</ref> The film was eventually released in 2009 directed by [[Zack Snyder]].
=== ''The Fighter'' === On March 26, 2007, Aronofsky announced that he was attached to direct ''[[The Fighter]]'', a biographical film based on the life of [[professional boxer]] [[Micky Ward]].<ref>{{cite web|author1=Pamela McClintock |author2=Michael Fleming |url=https://variety.com/2007/film/markets-festivals/aronofsky-in-talks-to-direct-fighter-2-1117961861/ |title=Aronofsky in talks to direct ‘Fighter’ |publisher=Variety |date=2007-03-26 |accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> [[Scott Silver]] was attached to write the script.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Michael Fleming |author2=Tatiana Siegel |url=https://variety.com/2007/film/features/brad-pitt-laces-up-for-fighter-2-1117972382/ |title=Brad Pitt laces up for ‘Fighter’ |publisher=Variety |date=2007-09-20 |accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> However, on July 25, 2008, [[Collider (website)|Collider]] reported that Aronofsky left the project in favor of directing the [[RoboCop (2014 film)|''RoboCop'' remake]].<ref name="collider1">{{cite web|author=Steve 'Frosty' Weintraub |url=http://collider.com/its-official-darren-aronofsky-will-build-a-better-robocop/ |title=It's Official! Darren Aronofsky Will Build A Better ROBOCOP |publisher=Collider |date=2008-07-25 |accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> The film was finally released in 2010 and directed by [[David O. Russell]].
=== ''RoboCop'' === On July 9, 2008, [[The Hollywood Reporter]] reported that [[MGM]] was in talks with Aronofsky to direct the long time planned ''[[RoboCop]]'' remake<ref>{{cite web|last=Fernandez |first=Jay A. |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/content_display/film/news/e3i2a7c68761043a405a4f5c48c0666d28e |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080710131402/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/content_display/film/news/e3i2a7c68761043a405a4f5c48c0666d28e |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2008-07-10 |title=MGM likes 'Dawn' at the 'Cabin' |date=2008-07-09 |accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> that was first announced in 2005. Sixteen days later, it was announced during the [[San Diego Comic-Con International]] 2008 that Aronofsky would direct the film with [[David Self]] attached to write it,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmjunk.com/2008/07/25/comic-con-rumour-control-aronosky-on-robocop-ratner-on-god-of-war-proyas-off-silver-surfer/ |title=Comic Con Rumour Control: Aronosky on Robocop, Ratner on God of War, Proyas off Silver Surfer |publisher=Film Junk |date=2008-07-25 |accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> leaving the production of [[Paramount Pictures]]' ''[[The Fighter]]''.<ref name="collider1"/> On June 12, 2009, it was reported that the film would be released in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|author=Gary Susman |url=http://io9.gizmodo.com/5288733/aronofskys-robocop-delayed-until-2011 |title=Aronofsky's Robocop Delayed Until 2011 |website=Io9.gizmodo.com |date= |accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> However, in July 2009, during the [[San Diego Comic-Con]], [[MGM]] reported that the project was slowing down due scheduling conflicts with Aronofsky.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slashfilm.com/mgm-looking-for-a-new-robocop-director-searchlight-wants-aronofskys-black-swan/ |title=MGM Looking For A New Robocop Director? Searchlight Wants Aronofsky's Black Swan - /Film |website=Slashfilm.com |date=2009-07-15 |accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> Finally, on March 2, 2011, it was reported by [[Internet Movie Database]] that Brazilian director [[José Padilha]] would direct the film instead of Aronofsky.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/news/ni8195625/|title=Jose Padilha in Talks to Direct Robocop Remake|website=IMDb.com|accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> The film was finally released in 2014 and directed by Padilha.
== 2010s == === ''Superman'' === On September 28, 2010, [[MTV News]] reported that Aronofsky was in talks with [[Warner Bros.]] to direct a [[Reboot (fiction)|reboot]] of the [[Superman in film|''Superman'' film series,]] after the not so good reception of ''[[Superman Returns]]'' in 2006.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/2597504/darren-aronofsky-superman-reboot/ |title=Darren Aronofsky Rumored For 'Superman' Reboot |publisher=MTV |date=2010-09-28 |accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> However, Aronofsky refused to direct it due his commitment with ''[[#The Wolverine|Wolverine 2]]''.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1725078/darren-aronofsky-superman/ |title=Darren Aronofsky 'Absolutely' Wanted To Direct 'Man Of Steel' |publisher=MTV |date=2014-03-31 |accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> A [[reboot (fiction)|reboot]] of the [[Superman in film|''Superman'' film series]] was finally released in 2013 as ''[[Man of Steel (film)|Man of Steel]]'' and directed by [[Zack Snyder]].
=== ''The Wolverine'' === On October 13, 2010, [[SuperHeroHype.com]] reported that Aronofsky was in talks with [[20th Century Fox]] to direct ''[[The Wolverine (film)|Wolverine 2]]'', the sixth entry of the [[X-Men (film series)|''X-Men'' film series]] that started with ''[[X-Men (film)|X-Men]]'' and the planned sequel of [[Gavin Hood]]'s poorly-received film ''[[X-Men Origins: Wolverine]]'',<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.superherohype.com/news/108795-darren-aronosfky-in-talks-for-wolverine-2 |title=Darren Aronofsky in Talks for Wolverine 2 |publisher=SuperHeroHype |date=2010-10-13 |accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> after ''[[X-Men (film)|X-Men]]'' director [[Bryan Singer]] turned down the offer of direct it in March 2010.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://herocomplex.latimes.com/movies/bryan-singer-and-the-xmen-together-again/ |title=Bryan Singer on ‘X-Men: First Class’: It’s got to be about Magneto and Professor X | Hero Complex – movies, comics, pop culture – Los Angeles Times |website=Herocomplex.latimes.com |date=2010-03-18 |accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> Seven days later, [[Hugh Jackman]] confirmed via [[Vulture.com]] that Aronofsky would direct the film.<ref>{{cite web|author=What to Stream Now |url=http://www.vulture.com/2010/10/hugh_jackman_promises_aronofsk.html |title=Hugh Jackman Promises Aronofsky’s Wolverine 2 Will Be ‘Thoughtful,’ ‘Meaty’ |publisher=Vulture |date= |accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> On November 13, 2010, Aronofsky confirmed via Upprox that the film would be titled now ''The Wolverine''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://uproxx.com/hitfix/darren-aronofsky-confirms-a-new-title-for-wolverine-2/ |title=Darren Aronofsky confirms a new title for ‘Wolverine 2’ |website=Uproxx.com |date= |accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> However, on March 17, 2011, ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' reported that Aronofsky left the project because directing would have meant that he had to leave his country for a long time and be away from his family.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/darren-aronofsky-bows-as-wolverine-168827 |title=Darren Aronofsky Bows Out as 'Wolverine' Director |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=2011-03-17 |accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> The film was finally released in 2013 and directed by [[James Mangold]].
=== ''Hobgoblin'' === On March 16, 2011, one day before announcing his departure from ''[[#The Wolverine|The Wolverine]]'' film, Aronofsky reported via ''[[Deadline Hollywood]]'' that he would direct the pilot of a planned TV series entitled ''Hobgoblin'' for [[HBO]]. The series would have focused on the adventures of a group of magicians and con artists who use their powers of deception to defeat [[Adolf Hitler]] during [[World War II]]. [[Pulitzer Prize]]-winning author [[Michael Chabon]] and Chabon's wife Ayelet Waldman were attached to work on the project.<ref>{{cite web|last=Andreeva |first=Nellie |url=http://deadline.com/2011/06/darren-aronofsky-joins-magic-world-war-ii-drama-series-in-development-at-hbo-140780/ |title=Darren Aronofsky Joins Magic World War II Drama Series In Development At HBO |website=Deadline Hollywood |date=2011-06-16 |accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> However, [[Screen Crush]] reported on June 18, 2013 that Aronofsky was pulled out from the project.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://screencrush.com/hbo-hobgoblin-darren-aronofsky-magic/ |title=HBO Passes on Darren Aronofsky WW2 Magic Drama 'Hobgoblin,' FX Reportedly Considers |website=Screencrush.com |date=2013-06-18 |accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref>
=== ''Red Sparrow'' === On August 14, 2013, Deadline.com reported that Aronofsky was in talks to direct a [[Red Sparrow|film adaptation]] of Jason Matthews' spy novel ''[[Red Sparrow (book)|Red Sparrow]]'',<ref>{{cite web|last=Fleming |first=Mike |url=http://deadline.com/2013/08/darren-aronofsky-in-talks-for-fox-espionage-tale-red-sparrow-564038/ |title=Darren Aronofsky In Talks For Fox Espionage Tale ‘Red Sparrow’ |website=Deadline Hollywood |date=2013-08-14 |accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> with [[Eric Warren Singer]] attached to write its script.<ref>{{cite web|author=Oliver Lyttelton |url=http://www.indiewire.com/2014/09/from-a-z-a-guide-to-the-lost-unmade-films-of-david-fincher-271772/ |title=From A-Z: A Guide To The Lost & Unmade Films Of David Fincher |publisher=[[IndieWire]] |date=2016-05-23 |accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> However, ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' later reported on January 16, 2014, that Aronofsky had abandoned the project.<ref>{{cite web|author=Borys Kit |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/darren-aronofsky-will-not-direct-671727 |title=Darren Aronofsky Will Not Direct 'Red Sparrow' |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=2014-01-16 |accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> On June 9, 2014, it was announced that [[David Fincher]] would direct the film, although no release date was announced at the moment.<ref>{{cite web|author=Rodrigo Perez |url=http://www.indiewire.com/2014/06/david-fincher-rooney-mara-possibly-reteaming-for-red-sparrow-adapted-by-american-hustle-screenwriter-85014/ |title=David Fincher & Rooney Mara Possibly Reteaming For ‘Red Sparrow’ Adapted By ‘American Hustle’ Screenwriter |publisher=[[IndieWire]] |date=2016-05-13 |accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> The film was eventually produced with [[Francis Lawrence]] directing.
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
{{Darren Aronofsky}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Farmhouse in Provence, 1888, Vincent van Gogh, NGA.jpg | title=Farmhouse in Provence | artist=Vincent van Gogh | year=1888 | medium=[[Oil on canvas]] | height_metric=46.1 | width_metric=60.9 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city=[[Washington, D.C.]] | museum=[[National Gallery of Art]] }} '''''Farmhouse in Provence''''' also known as '''''Entrance Gate to a Farm with Haystacks''''' was made in 1888 by [[Vincent van Gogh]] in [[Arles]] in [[Provence]] at the height of his career. Partially due to having been inspired by painter [[Adolphe Joseph Thomas Monticelli|Adolphe Monticelli]], Van Gogh sought the Provence region of France to further expand his painting skill and experience. Van Gogh used several pairs of complementary colors in the ''Farmhouse in Provence'', the color contrast bringing an intensity to his work. The painting is owned by the [[National Gallery of Art]] of [[Washington, D.C.]].
==Arles== At the time that Van Gogh painted ''Farmhouse in Provence'' he was 35 years old. Living in Arles, in southern France, he was at the height of his career, producing some of his best work,<ref name="Morton"/> such as fields, farmhouses and people of the Arles, Nîmes and Avignon area.<ref>{{cite book | title=Adventure Guide to Provence & the Cote D'azur | author=Arfin, F | publisher=Hunter Publishing | location=Edison, NJ | year=2009 | page= | isbn= | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SAQhVyHelOoC&pg=PA37 }}</ref>
The area was quite different than what he'd known in the Netherlands and Paris. The climate was hot and dry. People had dark hair and skin and spoke a different language than Parisian French. The colors were vivid. The terrain varied from plains to mountains. Here Van Gogh found a "brilliance and light that would wash out details and simplify forms, reducing the world around him to the sort of pattern he admired in [[Ukiyo-e|Japanese woodblocks]]" and where the "effect of the sun would strengthen the outlines of composition and reduce nuances of color to a few vivid contrasts."<ref name="NGA sun"/>
A prolific time, in less than 444 days Vincent made about 100 drawings and produced more than 200 paintings. Yet, he still wrote more than 200 letters. He described a series of seven studies of wheat fields as, "landscapes, yellow—old gold—done quickly, quickly, quickly, and in a hurry just like the harvester who is silent under the blazing sun, intent only on the reaping."<ref name="NGA sun">{{cite journal|last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |year= |title=Effects of the Sun in Provence |journal=National Gallery of Art Picturing France (1830-1900) |volume= |issue= |pages=121–123, 131 |publisher=National Gallery of Art |location=Washington, D.C. |doi= |url=http://www.nga.gov/education/classroom/france/picfrance_7.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110512000557/http://www.nga.gov/education/classroom/france/picfrance_7.pdf |archivedate=2011-05-12 |df= }}</ref>
In a letter to his brother, [[Theo van Gogh (art dealer)|Theo]], he wrote, "Painting as it is now, promises to become more subtle - more like music and less like sculpture - and above all, it promises color."<ref name="Morton">{{cite book | title=The Arts Entwined: Music and Painting in the Nineteenth Century | first1=M | last1=Morton | first2=P | last2=Schmunk | publisher=Garland Publishing | location=New York | year=2000 | pages=177–178 | isbn=0-8153-3156-8 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7NP724mFE1MC&pg=PA177 }}</ref>
==The painting== Van Gogh used three pairs of complementary, or contrasting, colors which when sat together intensified the brilliance and intensity of one another's colors. One pair is orange and blue. There's the red and green of the plants. Last, pink clouds against the turquoise sky.<ref name="NGA">{{cite web |url=http://www.nga.gov/fcgi-bin/tinfo_f?object=52178 |title=Farmhouse in Provence |author= |year=2011 |work=The Collection | publisher=National Gallery of Art |accessdate=March 24, 2011}}</ref>
Van Gogh used complementary, contrasting colors to bring an intensity to his work, which evolved over the periods of his work. Two complementary colors of the same degree of vividness and brightness placed next to one another produce an intense reaction, called the "law of simultaneous contrast."<ref>{{cite book | title=Van Gogh's Women: Vincent's Love Affairs and Journey Into Madness | author=Fell, D | publisher=Carroll & Graf Publishers | location=New York | year=2005 | origyear=2004 | page=64 | isbn=0-7867-1655-X | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lqSjxGgvVMMC&pg=PA64}}</ref>
Van Gogh mentioned the liveliness and interplay of "a wedding of two complementary colors, their mingling and opposition, the mysterious vibrations of two kindred souls."<ref name="Silverman326">{{cite book | title=Van Gogh and Gauguin: The Search for Sacred Art | author=Silverman, D | publisher=Farrar, Straus and Giroux | location=New York | year=2000 | page=326 | isbn=0-374-28243-9 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8c9jt9AToD0C&pg=PA326 }}</ref>
While in [[Nuenen]] Van Gogh became familiar with [[Michel Eugène Chevreul]]'s laws in weaving to maximize the intensity of colors through their contrast to adjacent colors.<ref name="Silverman140">{{cite book | title=Van Gogh and Gauguin: The Search for Sacred Art | author=Silverman, D | publisher=Farrar, Straus and Giroux | location=New York | year=2000 | page=140 | isbn=0-374-28243-9 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8c9jt9AToD0C&pg=PA140 }}</ref>
In Paris he was exposed through his brother Theo to [[Adolphe Joseph Thomas Monticelli|Adolphe Monticelli]]'s still life work with flowers, which he admired. First, he saw Monticelli's use of color as an expansion of Delacroix's theories of color and contrast. Secondly he admired the effect Monticelli created by heavy application of paint. It was partially Monticelli, from Marseilles, who inspired Van Gogh's southerly move to Provence. He felt such kinship for the man, and desire to emulate his style, that he wrote in a letter to his sister Wil that he felt as if he were "Monticelli's son or his brother."<ref name="Silverman438">{{cite book | title=Van Gogh and Gauguin: The Search for Sacred Art | author=Silverman, D | publisher=Farrar, Straus and Giroux | location=New York | year=2000 | page=438 | isbn=0-374-28243-9 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8c9jt9AToD0C&pg=PA438 }}</ref>
==Provenance== The National Gallery of Art reports the correct sequence of ownership for the painting is:<ref name="NGA-Prov">{{cite web |url=http://www.nga.gov/fcgi-bin/tinfo_f?object=52178&detail=prov |title=Farmhouse in Provence - Provenance |author= |year=2011 |work=The Collection |publisher=National Gallery of Art |accessdate=March 24, 2011}}</ref> * [[Johanna van Gogh-Bonger]] (1862-1925), the artist's sister-in-law, of [[Amsterdam]] sold the painting in November 1890 through Julien Tanguy Gallery, Paris to Willy Gretor, also known as Wilhelm Rudolph Julius Petersen (1868-1923) of Paris. Five paintings that were sold by Johanna became part of the [[National Gallery of Art]] collection. * Willy Gretor gifted the painting to [[Maria Slavona]], a German painter, of Paris and Berlin. It was one of many gifts of Van Gogh paintings by Willie to Maria, with whom he had a daughter, Lilly. Maria then married Otto Ackermann (1871-1963), an art dealer of Paris and Berlin. * From 1919 to at least 1933 Gaston Bernheim de Villers (1870-1953) of Paris owned the painting. * The painting was sold to Capt. Edward H. Molyneux (1891-1974) of Paris. * It was then sold August 15, 1955 to Ailsa Mellon Bruce (1901-1969) of New York. * In 1970 it was bequeathed to the National Gallery of Art, part of the Ailsa Mellon Bruce Collection.
Another sequence of ownership was given by J.-B. de la Faille in "The Works of Vincent van Gogh, His Paintings and Drawings" a portion of which was apparently in error (i.e., [[Bernheim-Jeune]], Reid and Lefevre, Ackermann, Molyneux.)<ref>J.B. de la Faille. (1970) ''The Works of Vincent van Gogh, His Paintings and Drawings.'' Reynal.</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Farmhouse in Provence}} * [http://www.nga.gov/fcgi-bin/timage_f?object=52178&image=12003&c= ''Farmhouse in Provence'', National Gallery of Art, Washington D.C.]
{{Vincent van Gogh}}

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{More footnotes|date=April 2010}} {{refimprove|date=April 2010}} }} '''FRIKAR dance company''' (established May 2006 by Hallgrim Hansegård) is a [[Norway|Norwegian]] dance company for contemporary and traditional dance specializing in the connection between dance and nature. ==History== '''FRIKAR dance company''' was founded by choreographer Hallgrim Hansegård in 2006, and has toured 29 countries all over the world. The company is described by National Geographic as "wildly inventive" and is composed by 32 artists from 4 continents (India, Iran, Somalia, Brazil, Cape Verde, France, Sweden, Norway.) The artists from very diverse genres meet each other in the research of gravity and human nature. With a background in Norwegian traditional dance choreographer Hallgrim Hansegård founded FRIKAR dance company to give acrobatic dancers living in Norway a creative environment. Together with the dancers he has been developing a new choreographical style for contemporary dance called "Down2Earth" including [[Hallingdans]] [[Capoeira]] and [[break dance]]. He works in the formats of aerial dance, site specific ecosophical stage arts, indoor dance and interdiciplinary arts. Hansegård made his international breakthrough with an animation film at the [[Venice Biennale]] in 2003 (Tarantrance). In 2005 he won 3rd prize at Superdok. In 2007 he was awarded "Artist of the Year" at The Norwegian Folk Music Awards. In 2009 he won the "Award for best choreography" at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2009]], among 43 countries in the most seen entertainment TV program in the world. In 2010 he premiered "Jamsiis" at Bergen International Festival [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fHSLBUOm9nc Youtube: Jamsiis]. This was a highly personal contribution to the Nordic contemporary dance scene, based on his roots in traditional dances. Jamsiis opened up a public discussion about the boundaries of contemporary dance in Norway. NRK (the Norwegian Broadcasting) writes:
JAMSIIS, Hallgrim Hansegårds new production, is the most exciting I have seen here. It’s very exciting to see traditional dance in dialogue with contemporary dance. Hansegård is branching out and opening up new territory here. He has come down a path that I think is very important to go. That Hansegård is a dancer with strong will to do his own thing and blessedly uninhibited as far as exceeding boundaries is concerned is something the Norwegian dance community should be happy about… At the same time that he approaches contemporary dance, he opens doors. If he succeeds in making contemporary dance accessible to a wider audience than today’s, the genre of contemporary dance should learn to endure a ‘halling-roundkick’ or two.Dance critic Karen Frøsland Nystøyl, NRK kulturnytt
In 2009 Hansegård directed TidarÅ, an outdoor full night dance performance under a waterfall with 22 dancers and musicians from FRIKAR dance company. The production collected contemporary and traditional dancers in a research for a unique contemporary dance technique. "Tidarå" is part of FRIKARs ecosophical productions. Hansegård directed also Yr in 2009 together with violin virtous Ragnhild Hemsing, premiere at the [[Bergen International Festival]]. In 2008 FRIKAR was censored by the [[Roman Catholic Church]] in [[Naples]] for his non conventional interpretation of Peer Gynt, [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jsip8vvC7gY NRK: Bukkerittet]. In the years 2005 to 2007 Hansegård directed "Undergrunnsfargo", "Isolations", "Laus", "Kruk", "The snuff grinders" and "Bastard". He also participated in ''[[Dansefeber]]'', the Norwegian version of ''[[So You Think You Can Dance (U.S. TV series)|So You Think You Can Dance]]'', in 2006.{{cite book |title=Hvem er hvem? |last= |first= |authorlink= |year=2008 |editor=Knut Olav Åmås |publisher=Aschehoug |location=Oslo |isbn=978-82-03-23561-0 |language=Norwegian |page=211 }} In 2008, his dancing was digitalized for the [[MMORPG|massively multiplayer online role-playing game]] (MMORPG) [[Age of Conan: Hyborian Adventures]].{{cite news|url=http://www.aftenposten.no/kul_und/spill/article2351271.ece|title=Et kast for Conan|work=[[Aftenposten]]|date=6 April 2008|first=Per Kristian|last=Bjørkeng|language=Norwegian|accessdate=18 May 2009}}{{cite book |title=Dans, estetikk og samfunn? |last= |first= |authorlink= |year=2010 |editor=Heidi Haraldsen |publisher=Tell Forlag |location=Oslo |isbn=978-82-7522-351-5 |language=Norwegian |pages=10, 25, 26, 51, 52, 57, 58.}} ==Choreographies / productions== - "AP" (2010) - "JAMSIIS" (2010) - "Wall dance" (2010) - "TidarÅ" (2009) - "YR" (2009) - "Fairytale" (2009) - "Mjølk" (2009" - "Bukkerittet" (2008) - "THE SNUFF GRINDERS" (2007) - "KRUK!" (2007) - "Bastard" (2007) - "LAUS" (2006) ==TV appearances== The whole company made it to the finals in [[Norske Talenter|Norway's Got Talent]] [[Norske Talenter (series 1)|in 2008]].{{cite web|url=http://www.folkemusikk.no/content/view/1662/1 |title=Frikar til Moskva! |publisher=Folkemusikk.no |date=22 February 2009 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=18 May 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090315050457/http://www.folkemusikk.no/content/view/1662/1/ |archivedate=March 15, 2009 }} Frikar performed with winner [[Alexander Rybak]] at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2009]] (ESC) performing "[[Fairytale (Alexander Rybak song)|Fairytale]]". The routine, based on traditional [[Halling (dance)|halling]] and choreographed by Hallgrim Hansegård, was awarded the Best Choreography of Eurovision 2009 by [[esctoday.com]].[http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/14709 Frikar Dance Company wins Best choreography award]. [[Eurovision Song Contest]] Today. 27-12-2009. Retrieved 30-05-2010. In 2009 Frikar performed 150 times,[http://frikar.com/ FRIKAR dance company]. Retrieved 30-05-2010. including its outdoor big scale production TidarÅ, concerts with the [[Oslo Philharmonic Orchestra]], the premiere "YR" at [[Bergen International Art Festival]]. They toured 20 European countries with live performances and TV shows.[http://frikar.com/frikar-bio-en.pdf FRIKAR dance company - THE FAIRYTALE] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160127211813/http://frikar.com/frikar-bio-en.pdf |date=2016-01-27 }}. Retrieved 30-05-2010. FRIKAR was censored by the [[Catholic Church]] on their 2008 Italy tour for an unromanticized interpretation of [[Peer Gynt]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} Frikar also won the "Norway's got talent" competition in 2008. ==External links== * [http://www.frikar.com/ FRIKAR dance company website] *{{Cite news |last=Rütter |first=Fredrik |title=Eksotisk med FRIKAR |url= http://www.vg.no/rampelys/artikkel.php?artid=10005336 |work=VG |date= 5 May 2010 |accessdate=5 May 2010}} *{{cite news |last= |first= |title=Choreographer Hallgrim Hansegård: 'NRK about Hansegård' |url=http://www.vimeo.com/19149785 |work=The Norwegian Broadcasting Corporation |date=31 October 2009 |accessdate=31 October 2009 | location=Oslo}} *{{cite news |last=Befort |first=Anna |title=FRIKAR´s modern fairytale |url=http://www.frikar.com/frikar.pdf |work=Viking Magazine |date=June 2011 |accessdate=June 2011 |location=US |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160127211813/http://www.frikar.com/frikar.pdf |archivedate=2016-01-27 |df= }} *{{cite news |last=Christensen |first=Ann |title=Vraker Frikar, tar styringen selv |url=http://www.aftenposten.no/kul_und/article3854527.ece |work=Aftenposten |date=17 November 2009 |accessdate=17 November 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101015023241/http://www.aftenposten.no/kul_und/article3854527.ece |archivedate=15 October 2010 |df= }} *{{cite news |last=Tofte |first=Per |title=En suksess vrakes |url=http://www.aftenposten.no/meninger/debatt/article3868692.ece |work=The Independent |date=6 November 2009 |accessdate=6 November 2009 |location=Oslo |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121011070021/http://www.aftenposten.no/meninger/debatt/article3868692.ece |archivedate=11 October 2012 |df= }} *{{cite news |last=Borgersen |first=Vibeke |title=Kreativ Energi |url=http://www.frikar.com/mobile/kreativ-energi |work=Aftenposten |date=23 October 2010 |accessdate=23 October 2010 |location=Oslo }}{{dead link|date=October 2017 [[File:El hombre amigable.jpg|thumb|Greetingman statue, [[Buceo]] neighbourhood, [[Montevideo, Uruguay]].]] '''''Greetingman''''' ({{lang-ko|그리팅맨}}) is a modern sculpture project in South Korea.
Its main artist is [[Yoo Young-ho]] (South Korean sculptor). The concept provides a man, 6 m high, [[bowing]] in a typically Asian greeting gesture. The blue color means lack of prejudice.
In October 2012, a statue was unveiled in the neighbourhood of [[Buceo]], [[Montevideo]], [[Uruguay]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elpais.com.uy/121020/pespec-670696/espectaculos/Escultura-coreana-en-rambla-de-Buceo/ |title=Korean sculpture on the Montevidean seashore|date=2012-10-20|publisher=EL PAIS}} {{es icon}}</ref> as part of a planned world series in multiple locations.<ref>[http://www.greetingman.com/future.html Future of Greetingman]</ref><ref>[http://english.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_entertainment/486476.html One thousand greetings]''The Hankyoreh''. 8 July 2011</ref>
Another statue was unveiled in October 2013 in [[South Korea]], near the [[Korean Demilitarized Zone]], in Haean, [[Yanggu County, Gangwon]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://english.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_national/608543.html |title=Greeting Man statue coming to Korean War battleground |publisher=The Hankyoreh |date=25 October 2013}}</ref>
A third statue was unveiled in January 2016 in [[Panama City, Panama]], the second to be unveiled in Latin America.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://laestrella.com.pa/estilo/cultura/develan-escultura-degreetingman-costa-este/23917137/foto/205961 |title=Develan escultura de "Greetingman" en la ciudad de Panamá |publisher=La Estrella de Panamá |date=20 January 2016}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Korean sculpture]] *[[Public art in South Korea]]
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} '''Hugo Cecil Levinge Rumbold''' (7 February 1884 – 19 November 1932) was an English designer of theatrical scenery and costumes. Among those who commissioned designs from him were [[Herbert Beerbohm Tree|Sir Herbert Tree]], [[Thomas Beecham|Sir Thomas Beecham]], [[Arthur Bourchier]] and [[Rupert D'Oyly Carte]].
==Life and career== Rumbold was born in Stockholm, the younger son of the diplomat [[Sir Horace Rumbold, 8th Baronet|Sir Horace Rumbold]] and his second wife, Louisa Anne (d. 1940), daughter of [[Thomas Russell Crampton]]. His elder half-brother was another diplomat, also called [[Sir Horace Rumbold, 9th Baronet|Horace Rumbold]].<ref>Otte, T. G. [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/35866 "Rumbold, Sir Horace George Montagu, 9th Baronet (1869–1941)",] ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography'', [[Oxford University Press]] (2004), accessed 10 Nov 2007 {{ODNBsub}}</ref>
Rumbold went to [[Eton College|Eton]] in 1897. He was commissioned a [[second lieutenant]] in the 7th ([[Militia (United Kingdom)|Militia]]) Battalion of the [[Rifle Brigade (The Prince Consort's Own)]] in 1901<ref>Hart′s Army list, 1902</ref> and served in South Africa during the [[Second Boer War]]. He was promoted to lieutenant in June 1902, the same month the war ended, and soon returned to England.<ref>"The Army in South Africa – Troops returning Home", ''[[The Times]]'', 15 September 1902, p. 10</ref> He served with the [[Grenadier Guards]] in the [[First World War]], during which he was wounded and received the [[Order of the Crown (Belgium)]]. In civilian life, he was sometimes referred to by his military title of Captain H. C. L. Rumbold.<ref name=times>''The Times'', 21 November 1932, p. 19</ref>
===Stage design=== [[File:PC rumbold.jpg|right|upright|thumb|Rumbold's costumes for ''[[Patience (opera)|Patience]]'']] As a stage designer, Rumbold's early work included "[[Pre-Raphaelite]]" sets and costumes for [[William Faversham]]'s ''[[Romeo and Juliet]]'' in 1913;<ref>[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A07E7DC1F3BE633A25752C2A9649D946296D6CF "Hugo Rumbold Attacks Realism in Stage Scenery; Thinks Belasco and Tree Are Wrong"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', 21 December 1913, p. SM9</ref> and Tudor décor and costumes for [[Arthur Bourchier]]'s production of ''Bluff King Hal'', the following year. ''[[The Observer]]'' considered Rumbold's contribution the best thing about the show, and said, "His costumes and his scenes at Greenwich, Westminster and Hampton Court show considerable power of being original within the limits of archaeology and probability; and, though inexperience peeps out here and there, the work as a whole is splendid and beautiful."<ref>"Bluff King Hal", ''The Observer'', 6 September 1914, p. 3</ref> In the following years his designs included ''The Right to Kill'', a melodrama set in Turkey staged by [[Herbert Beerbohm Tree|Sir Herbert Tree]] at [[Her Majesty's Theatre|His Majesty's Theatre]];<ref>''The Times'', 5 May 1915, p. 13</ref> and [[Charles Villiers Stanford]]'s opera ''The Critic'' (based on [[Richard Brinsley Sheridan|Sheridan's]] [[The Critic (play)|play of the same name]]) at the [[Shaftesbury Theatre]] in 1916, of which ''[[The Times]]'' said, "Mr Hugo Rumbold apparently carries the 18th century atmosphere about in his pocket."<ref>''The Times'', 13 January 1916, p. 11</ref> He also designed ''L'Apres Midi d'un Faune'' in 1916.<ref>[http://www.brynmawr.edu/library/speccoll/guides/fraser.shtml Profile of Claud Lovat Fraser, Claud Lovat Fraser and Grace Crawford Lovat Fraser Collections, Bryn Mawr College Library Special Collections, accessed 10 July 2014]</ref>
Rumbold was commissioned by [[Rupert D'Oyly Carte]] to dress a 1918 revival of [[Gilbert and Sullivan]]'s ''[[Patience (opera)|Patience]],'' in succession to [[W. S. Gilbert]], who designed the original costumes, and [[Percy Anderson]], who dressed the 1907 revival. Some of Rumbold's costumes (for the "everyday young girls") were retained by the [[D'Oyly Carte Opera Company]] until [[Peter Goffin]]'s new designs were introduced in 1957.<ref>Rollins and Witts, Appendix, pp. vii and viii</ref> For [[Thomas Beecham|Sir Thomas Beecham]], Rumbold designed revivals of ''[[La fille de Madame Angot]]'', by [[Alexandre Charles Lecocq|Lecocq]], and [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart|Mozart]]'s ''[[Le Nozze di Figaro]]'' staged at the [[Theatre Royal, Drury Lane]] in 1919.<ref>''The Times'', 30 June 1919, p. 10</ref> In the same year he designed the first British production of [[Maurice Ravel|Ravel]]'s ''[[L'heure espagnole]]'' for [[Royal Opera House|Covent Garden]].<ref>"Hugo Rumbold", ''[[The Daily Mail]]'', 21 November 1932, p. 10</ref> Rumbold designed a revival of [[George Bernard Shaw|Bernard Shaw]]'s ''[[Arms and the Man]]'' at the [[Duke of York's Theatre]] in 1919,<ref>''The Times'', 12 December 1919, p. 12</ref> and ''[[The Tempest]]'' for [[Viola Tree]]'s company at the [[Aldwych Theatre]] in 1921.<ref>''The Times'', 2 February 1921, p. 8</ref>
===Other theatrical work=== In 1920 Rumbold acted as impresario, producing [[Darius Milhaud]]'s new ballet, ''[[Le bœuf sur le toit]]'' at the [[Coliseum Theatre]], under the title ''The Nothing Doing Bar''.<ref>''The Times'', Monday, 12 July 1920, p. 12</ref> This departure from his milieu was noted in his obituary notice in ''The Times'', which said: "He was essentially a [[Bohemian]] and a clubman, who was witty and amusing and always tried to pass on his zest for life to others.... Later, he took to film-producing. He was indeed something of a dilettante and dabbler in many pursuits. Had he been more of a 'sticker' he would have made more of a name for himself."<ref name=times/> With [[Zoë Akins]], he wrote ''The Human Elephant'', a play in three acts adapted from the short story of that title by [[Somerset Maugham]].<ref>[http://www.nypl.org/research/manuscripts/berg/brgmaugh.xml List of manuscripts], New York Public Library, accessed 10 July 2013</ref>
===Personal life and death=== Rumbold was described as "one of the Last of the Dandies" and a "brilliant flâneur".<ref>Montesole, Max. [http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article32955808 "Little memories of big people"], ''[[The West Australian]]'', 22 September 1934, p. 7</ref> He was a member of [[Noël Coward]]'s set, with a penchant for [[cross-dressing]] in pursuit of comic turns at parties, according to Coward's biographer [[Philip Hoare]]<ref>Hoare, p. 107</ref> and [[Faith Compton Mackenzie]], whose clothes he borrowed in 1904.<ref>Compton Mackenzie, pp. 165–167</ref> Despite the mutual hostility of Coward and [[the Sitwells]], Rumbold maintained a friendship with all of them.<ref>Lloyd, p. 61</ref> [[Charlie Chaplin]] said that as a mimic he had never known anyone to compare with Rumbold.<ref>[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article29608801 "How to Entertain Royalty on £1500 a Year"], ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]], 6 January 1954</ref> In the last year of his life, Rumbold married the dramatist [[Zoë Akins]].<ref>"Zoe Akins to be Wed to Hugo Rumbold", ''The New York Times'', 8 March 1932; and Porter, p. 105</ref>
Rumbold died in [[Pasadena, California]], in 1932, aged 48, from an illness caused by his injuries in World War I.<ref name=times/> He is buried at San Gabriel Cemetery, [[San Gabriel, California|San Gabriel]], California.<ref>[https://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=7906288 "Hugo Cecil Levinge "Hugh" Rumbold (1884–1932)"], Find a Grave, accessed July 23, 2017</ref>
==Notes== {{reflist|2}}
==References== * {{cite book |last1=Compton Mackenzie |first1=Faith | authorlink=Faith Compton Mackenzie| title=As Much as I Dare |date=1938 |publisher=Collins |location=Pall Mall, London| isbn= }} * {{cite book | last= Hoare | first= Philip | year= 1995| title= Noel Coward | location= London | publisher= Sinclair-Stevenson | isbn= 1-85619-265-2}} * {{cite book | last= Lloyd | first= Stephen | year= 2001| title= William Walton : muse of fire | location= Woodbridge | publisher= Boydell Press | isbn= 085115803X}} *{{cite book|title=Katharine the Great|first=Darwin |last= Porter|year=2004|publisher=Blood Moon Productions|isbn=0-9748118-0-7|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SMz8ixHYU30C&pg=PA105&lpg=PA105&dq=%22hugo+rumbold%22&source=web&ots=g_1LL2cN2b&sig=NHfY9QAGFhqgSJMfdP5GwV81ECk}} * {{cite book|last=Rollins|first=Cyril|year=1962|author2=R. John Witts |title=The D'Oyly Carte Opera Company in Gilbert and Sullivan Operas: A Record of Productions, 1875–1961| location=London|publisher=Michael Joseph|oclc=504581419}}
==External links== *{{IBDB name|25281}} * [http://archives.nypl.org/the/21387 Costume designs for The tempest, 1921], held by the Billy Rose Theatre Division, [[New York Public Library for the Performing Arts]]

revision.text:
{{No footnotes|date=October 2017}} [[File:Eperjeske.jpg|250px|thumb|right|The most characteristic decorative motif is the [[palmette]] style as on this [[sabretache]] plate.]] <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Csempkopacs.jpg|250px|thumb|left|One of the most beautiful heritage from the old Romanesque architectural art: the village church at Csempeszkopács.]] --> [[File:Nagytotlak.JPG|250px|thumb|right|Several Romanesque village churches in Hungary were constructed in rotunda form, as here at Nagytótlak.]] '''Hungarian art''' stems from the period of the conquest of the [[Carpathian basin]] by the people of [[Árpád]] in the 9th century. Prince Árpád also organized earlier people settled in the area.
==Horsemen in the Carpathian basin== Before the arrival of Árpád several other peoples from the steppe had founded states in the Carpathian basin. The capital of the Huns (Xiongnu in Chinese) was [[Bleda|Buda]], named after King Attila's brother, though [[Priscus]] rhetor, a 5th-century historian and ambassador of the [[Byzantine Empire]] stated that the capital of the Huns was in the plains between the [[Danube]] and [[Tisza]] rivers. After the death of [[Attila]] in 453 the [[Lombards]] and [[Gepids]], and later the [[Avars (Carpathians)|Avars]] founded states here (569). This late Avar kingdom was defeated by the [[Franks]], and the Avars of Transdanubia were baptised. The first Hungarians came to the basin during the late 9th century.
==Art of the Conquest period== The People of Árpád in the 9th century used beautiful ornamental motifs to decorate both their dress and the trappings of their horses, the main motif being the palmette (see the above illustration). This style remained important in Hungary from the 9th to the 11th centuries, and similar motifs can be found in the contemporary decorative arts of the Caucasus, Iran and Middle-Asia.
==Arts in the Romanesque age== Descendants of Prince Árpád organized the medieval Hungarian Kingdom. During this period the combination of styles originating in the steppes with those of the European [[Romanesque art|Romanesque]] produced a rich heritage, with noticeable parallels in the art of the Scandinavian Vikings and the Celts of Western Europe. The coronation mantle of [[Stephen I of Hungary|King Stephen]] (crowned 1000 A. D.) is a particularly fine example from this period.[[File:PALAST.jpg|250px|thumb|right|The coronation mantle of Hungary from the time of King [[Stephen I of Hungary]], reigned 1000-1038 A. D.]]
This king stated that "10 villages should build a church", and though several of his foundations were later famous in new guises, they all date back to the ''lex Stephani'' (law of King Stephen). [[File:Romanikapukon.JPG|left|250px|thumb| Tympani from Romanesque village churches in Medieval Hungary: Monoszló, Domokosfa, Halmágy and the arch of Csempeszkopács with the lamb of Szeged.]]
===Church architecture and sculpture=== In spite of widespread destruction during the Turkish occupation (c1526-1686, and see below), Romanesque churches and other ecclesiastical buildings can be found throughout the Carpathian basin. Fine examples survive at [[Székesfehérvár]], [[Gyulafehérvár]], [[Esztergom]], [[Pannonhalma]], while recently opened lapidariums at [[Pécs]], [[Veszprém]], and [[Eger]] display remains from this period. Ruins of former royal houses at Tarnaszentmária, Feldebrő, and [[Szekszárd]], also show stylistic resemblances to contemporary architecture from the Caucasus.
Large-scale reconstructions were undertaken after the Mongolian wars of 1241-42. Many beautiful village churches survive from this periods, both round churches ([[Szalonna (village)|Szalonna]], [[Kallósd]] and [[Nagytótlak]]), and those with western tower and southern doorway at [[Nagybörzsöny]], [[Csempeszkopács]], [[Őriszentpéter]], [[Magyarszecsőd]], [[Litér]], [[Velemér]] and [[Zalaháshágy]]. [[File:Velemer.JPG|250px|thumb|right|Romanesque village churches were often decorated with frescoes especially on the north wall, as here at Velemér.]]
==Gothic art== The Gothic style reached Hungary in the late 14th century, and continued throughout the reigns of the Anjou, Luxembourg, and Jagello kings. Wealthy mining towns have built them on their main square like as at such as [[Košice|Kassa]] (Košice, [[Slovakia]]), [[Bártfa]] (Bardejov, [[Slovakia]]), [[Braşov|Brassó]] and [[Nagyszeben]] built their main squares in this style,which can also be seen in several rebuilt monasteries, for example ([[Garamszentbenedek]] in [[Slovakia]]). The now destroyed monastery of the [[The Order of Saint Paul the First Hermit|Pauline Order]] at Budaszentlőrinci was also built in this style.
The most renowned architect of this time was János Mester, a [[Franciscan]] brother. His largest churches are in Szeged-Alsóváros, in Farkas Street, Kolozsvár (Cluj, [[Romania]]), and in Nyirbátor. Perhaps the most famous Hungarian Gothic church of all is the Cathedral of St Elizabeth in [[Košice|Kassa]] (Košice, [[Slovakia]]).
[[File:SzentGyorgy.JPG|250px|thumb|right|An equestrian sculpture of Saint George, by the Kolozsvári brothers.]] [[File:TereskeSztLaszlo.JPG|250px|thumb|left|Detail of the mural of Saint Ladislaus in the church of Tereske, Northern Hungary.]]
=== Sculptures and paintings === The rich heritage of paintings in Hungary originated with the royal houses of Luxemburg and Anjou, that both esteemed the earlier king [[Ladislaus I of Hungary|Ladislaus I]]. (Both [[Sigismund, Holy Roman Emperor|Sigismund of Luxemburg, King of Hungary and Holy Roman Emperor]], and Louis The Great, King of Hungary and Poland were buried in the cathedral of Nagyvárad at the side of King Ladislaus.) Even today, after so many wars and so much destruction, there are about fifty churches where murals of the [[Saint Ladislaus legend]] can be found.
== Renaissance == [[File:111 Matthias Corvinus florint 755820.jpg|200px|right|A gold Florin of King Mátyás (Matthias).]] King [[Matthias Corvinus of Hungary]] had close ties with Italy, and Italian influence is clearly evident in architectural complexes built during his reign, such as his palaces in [[Buda]] and in [[Visegrád|Visegrad]]. A recent exhibition at the mining Museum in [[Rudabánya]] displayed the quality of Hungarian goldwork at this period in the golden forints made by Hungarian masters for the Russian Tsar Ivan III. 2008 saw the 550th anniversary of Matthias' reign, and many items from his library, the Bibliotheca Corvina (once the largest in Europe) were displayed in the National Széchényi Library in [[Buda Castle]] [http://www.corvina.oszk.hu link] === Reformation === [[File:Tulipkazetta.jpg|150px|thumb|left|A ceiling "cassette" with tulip motifs in a Hungarian village church]] [[File:Sárospatak - Castle.jpg|thumb|250px|The fortress of Sárospatak: a keep with surrounding bailey; the baroque castle (upper right) is a much later addition.]]
During the same period as the Wars against the Turks and the beginning of the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] occupation, [[the Reformation]] led to a change of religious allegiance in about one third of Hungary. This time was also aperiod of renewal for churches in an architectural sense, with inner spaces displaying fresh and delicate ornamentation, particularly in the use of plant forms. "Cassette" ceilings are also characteristic of this period.
===Architecture of fortresses=== The wars against the [[Ottoman Empire]] also led to great developments in the construction of Hungarian fortresses. Earlier fortresses had been built before the era of heavy artillery, but were now fortified to resist it. The best-known surviving fortresses from this period are those of [[Eger]], [[Nagyvárad]], [[Nagykanizsa]] and [[Érsekújvár]] (Nové Zámky in Slovakia).
==Baroque reconstruction== [[File:Basilika eger.jpg|250px|thumb|left|The most prominent cathedral in the neo-classical style is the Basilica of Eger.]] After the expulsion of the Turks in 1686, the new ruling house of the [[Habsburg]]s brought with it the new Baroque style. Most of the early surviving buildings in Hungary today are in this style: not only churches, but also castles e.g. [[Fertőd]], town halls ([[Szeged]]), monasteries ([[Zirc]]), cathedrals ([[Kalocsa]]), colleges ([[Eger]]) and the royal palace at [[Buda]].
==Neo-classicism== After the Age of Reform, in the early 19th century ancient Greek traditions were revived, with the consequent construction of such neo-Classical buildings as the [[Hungarian National Museum]].
== Secessionism or Jugendstil == One of the greatest architects of his age was [[Ödön Lechner]], who planned the Museum of Trade Art, The Hungarian Geological Institute, the town hall of [[Kecskemét]], and the Saint Ladislaus Church at Kőbánya, Budapest. Sometimes he is called the Hungarian [[Gaudi]]. [[File:Földtani intézet - Budapest.jpg|thumbnail|250px|right|The building of the Hungarian Geological Institute, Budapest.]]
==See also== *[[Anjou Legendarium]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

The Hungarian Renaissance Art. Képzőművészeti Alap Kiadóvállalata, Budapest] * [Aradi N. (főszerk.) (Ész. N.): A művészet története Magyarországon. revision.comment: Link to Knausgaard book, not Hitler's
revision.text:
{{italictitle}} A '''''Künstlerroman''''' ({{IPA-de|ˈkʏnstlɐ.ʁoˌmaːn}}; plural -ane), meaning "artist's novel" in English, is a [[narrative]] about an artist's growth to maturity.<ref name="Werlock2010p387">Werlock, James P. (2010) [https://books.google.com/books?id=lWuyTK_0eBsC&pg=PA387 The Facts on File companion to the American short story], Volume 2, p.387</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=bflZc3a6mxMC&pg=PA13&dq=Künstlerroman+definition&hl=en&sa=X&ei=SRYKUpPWD-bkyQH51oHADQ&ved=0CCEQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Künstlerroman%20definition&f=false A Studio of One's Own: Fictional Women Painters and the Art of Fiction] by Roberta White (page 13) published 2005 by Rosemont Publishing & Printing Crops. Accessed Via Google Books August 13, 2013.</ref>
It may be classified as a specific subgenre of ''[[Bildungsroman]]'';<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=MN4ZRn3D5PsC&pg=PA128&dq=Künstlerroman+definition&hl=en&sa=X&ei=SRYKUpPWD-bkyQH51oHADQ&ved=0CEYQ6AEwCg#v=onepage&q=Künstlerroman%20definition&f=false Germaine de Staël in Germany: Gender and Literary Authority] by Judith E. Martin (page 128) 2001 Fairleigh & Dickinson University Press</ref> such a work, usually a novel, tends to depict the conflicts of a sensitive youth against the values of a middle and upper class society of his or her time.
==Examples== ;In German *[[Johann Wolfgang von Goethe]]'s 1795 ''[[Wilhelm Meister's Apprenticeship]]'' *[[Ludwig Tieck]]'s 1798 ''[[Franz Sternbalds Wanderungen]]'' *[[Novalis]]'s 1802 ''[[Heinrich von Ofterdingen]]'' *[[Hermann Hesse]]'s ''[[Demian]]'' (1919) and ''[[Klingsor's Last Summer]]'' (1920) *[[Thomas Mann]]'s ''[[Tonio Kröger]]'' (1903), and ''[[Doctor Faustus (novel)|Doctor Faustus]]'' (1947) *[[Jakob Wassermann]]'s 1915 ''[[Das Gänsemännchen]]'' *[[Rainer Maria Rilke]]'s 1910 ''[[The Notebooks of Malte Laurids Brigge]]''
; In English {{div col|colwidth=30em}} *1805 [[William Wordsworth]]'s ''[[The Prelude]]'' *1847 [[Charlotte Brontë]]'s ''[[Jane Eyre]]'' *1848 [[Anne Brontë]]'s ''[[The Tenant of Wildfell Hall]]'' *1850 [[Charles Dickens]]' ''[[David Copperfield]]'' *1852 [[Herman Melville]]'s ''[[Pierre: or, The Ambiguities]]'' *1856 [[Elizabeth Barrett Browning]]'s ''[[Aurora Leigh]]'' *1875 [[Henry James]]'s ''[[Roderick Hudson]]'' *1890 [[Henry James]]'s ''[[The Tragic Muse]]'' *1903 [[Samuel Butler (novelist)|Samuel Butler]]'s ''[[The Way of All Flesh]]'' *1909 [[Jack London]] ''[[Martin Eden]]'' *1913 [[D. H. Lawrence]]'s ''[[Sons and Lovers]]'' *1915 [[W. Somerset Maugham]]'s ''[[Of Human Bondage]]'' *1915 [[Willa Cather]]'s ''[[The Song of the Lark]]'' *1916 [[James Joyce]]'s ''[[A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man]]''<ref name="Werlock2010p387"/> *1918 [[Wyndham Lewis]]'s ''[[Tarr]]'' *1920 [[F. Scott Fitzgerald]]'s ''[[This Side of Paradise]]'' *1928 [[Radclyffe Hall]]'s ''[[The Well of Loneliness]]'' *1929 [[Thomas Wolfe]]'s ''[[Look Homeward, Angel]]'' *1933 [[Malcolm Lowry]]'s [[Ultramarine (novel)|''Ultramarine'']] *1936 [[George Orwell]]'s ''[[Keep the Aspidistra Flying]]'' *1939 [[John Fante]]'s ''[[Ask the Dust]]'' *1945 [[Richard Wright (author)|Richard Wright]]'s ''[[Black Boy]]'' *1947 [[W. O. Mitchell|W.O. Mitchell]]'s ''[[W. O. Mitchell#Quotation|Who Has Seen the Wind]]'' *1952 [[Patricia Highsmith]]'s ''[[The Price of Salt]]'' *1955 [[William Gaddis]]'s ''[[The Recognitions]]'' *1961 [[Irving Stone]]'s ''[[The Agony and the Ecstasy (novel)|The Agony and the Ecstasy]]'' *1970 [[Patrick White]]'s ''[[The Vivisector]]'' *1971 [[Alice Munro]]'s ''[[Lives of Girls and Women]]'' *1972 [[Chaim Potok]]'s ''[[My Name Is Asher Lev]]'' *1973 [[Milan Kundera]]'s ''[[Life Is Elsewhere]]'' *1974 [[Margaret Laurence]]'s ''[[The Diviners]]'' *1978 [[John Irving]]'s ''[[The World According to Garp]]'' *1981 [[Alasdair Gray]]'s ''[[Lanark: A Life in Four Books]]'' *1982 [[Charles Bukowski]]'s ''[[Ham on Rye]]''<ref>[[David Stephen Calonne|Calonne, David Stephen]]. Charles Bukowski. Reaktion Books, London, 2012. p. 146. {{ISBN|978-1-78023-023-8}}</ref> *1988 [[Margaret Atwood]]'s ''[[Cat's Eye (novel)|Cat's Eye]]'' *1999 [[Tracy Chevalier]]'s ''[[Girl with a Pearl Earring (novel)|Girl with a Pearl Earring]]''<ref>Miriam de Paiva Vieira, "From Canvas to Paper: The Novel by Tracy Chevalier", [http://www.bibliotecadigital.ufmg.br/dspace/bitstream/handle/1843/ECAP-7A3H7K/dissertacao_mestrado_miriam_vieira.pdf?sequence=1 ''Art and New Media: Vermeer’s Work under Different Semiotic Systems''] p.19</ref> *2003 [[Jennifer Donnelly]]'s ''[[A Northern Light]]'' *2006 [[Alison Bechdel]]'s ''[[Fun Home]]'' *2006 [[Stew (musician)|Stew]]'s ''[[Passing Strange]]'' *2010 [[Eileen Myles]]'s ''Inferno (A Poet's Novel)'' *2010 [[Wena Poon]]'s ''Alex y Robert'', the Asian American ''Künstlerroman'' {{div col end}}
[[Alasdair Gray]]'s ''[[Lanark: A Life in Four Books]]'' consists of four books arranged in the order 3, 1, 2, 4; books 1 and 2 constituting a ''Künstlerroman''. In [[John Dos Passos]]' [[U.S.A. trilogy]], the ''Camera Eye'' sections add up to a [[modernism|modernist]] [[autobiography|autobiographical]] ''Künstlerroman''. [[John Barth]]'s ''[[Lost in the Funhouse]]'' is a collection of short stories that are often read as a [[postmodernism|postmodernist]] ''Künstlerroman''.
; In French *1831, 1837 [[Honore de Balzac]]'s ''[[The Unknown Masterpiece]]'' *1904–1905 [[Romain Rolland]]'s ''[[Jean-Christophe]]'' *1913- 1927 [[Marcel Proust]]'s ''[[In Search of Lost Time]]''<ref>John Neary [https://books.google.com/books?id=CpOa5vsGx34C&pg=PA54 ''Something and nothingness: the fiction of John Updike & John Fowles''] p.54</ref><ref>Gilles Deleuze. ''Marcel Proust et les signes''. Paris: PUF, 1964]</ref>
;In Italian *[[Gabriele D'Annunzio]]'s ''Il Piacere'', ''Le Vergini Delle Rocce'' and ''Il Fuoco'' *1975 [[Gavino Ledda]]'s ''My Father, My Master'' (''Padre Padrone'')
;In Icelandic *[[Halldór Laxness]]'s ''[[World Light]]'' *[[Halldór Laxness]]'s [[The Fish Can Sing]]
;In Russian *[[Vladimir Nabokov]]'s ''[[The Gift (Nabokov novel)|The Gift]]''
;In Croatian: *1932 [[Miroslav Krleža]]'s ''[[The Return of Filip Latinovicz]]''
;In [[Malayalam]]: *1993 [[Perumbadavam Sreedharan]]'s ''[[Oru Sankeerthanam Pole]]''
;In [[Norwegian language|Norwegian]]: *2009-2011 [[Karl Ove Knausgaard]]'s ''[[My Struggle (Knausgård novels)]]''
;In [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]]: *1883 [[Maria Benedita Bormann]]'s ''Lésbia''<ref>{{citation|last1=Rodríguez|first1=Ileana|first2=Mónica|last2=Szurmuk|title=The Cambridge History of Latin American Women's Literature|type=ebook|location=New York|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2015|page=212|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LbvbCgAAQBAJ&pg=PT212}}</ref> *1976 [[Ferreira Gullar]]'s ''Poema Sujo''
;In [[Turkish language|Turkish]]: *1896-1897 [[Halit Ziya Uşaklıgil]]'s ''Blue and Black'' (''Mavi ve Siyah'')
;In [[ Bengali language ]] 1999 [[Malay Roy Choudhury]]s [[Chhotoloker Chhotobela ]]
==References== {{reflist}}

page.title: List of publications by Ottaviano Petrucci

revision.comment: Replace [[Help:Magic_links|magic links]] with templates per [[Special:PermaLink/772743896#Future_of_magic_links|local RfC]] - [[User:PrimeBOT/13|BRFA]]
revision.text:
This is a list of all known publications by [[Ottaviano Petrucci]], an influential Italian printer of the 16th century. Most of these were reprinted several times during Petrucci's life, but in this list only dates of first publication are given. Some of the earlier publications (for instance, the [[Josquin des Prez|Josquin]] masses) were reprinted separately, in [[Fossombrone]], after Petrucci moved there around 1510; these reprints are listed. The vast majority of Petrucci's publications were published in [[Venice]]; those from his Fossombrone years are marked accordingly.
==List of publications== ===Vocal=== ====Secular==== * ''[[Harmonice Musices Odhecaton]] A'' (1501; 2nd ed, 1503; 3rd ed, 1504) * ''Canti B numero cinquanta'' (1502; 2nd ed, 1503) * ''Canti C cento cinquanta'' (1504) * ''Frottole I'' (1504) * ''Frottole II'' (1505) * ''Frottole III'' (1505) * ''Frottole IV'' (1505) * ''Frottole V'' (1505) * ''Frottole VI'' (1506) * ''Frottole VII'' (1507) * ''Frottole IX'' (1509) * ''[[Franciscus Bossinensis]]: Tenori e contrabassi I'' (1509) * ''Franciscus Bossinensis: Tenori e contrabassi II'' (1511, Fossombrone) * ''Frottole X'' (1512, Fossombrone, lost) * ''Frottole XI'' (1514, Fossombrone) * ''[[Bernardo Pisano]]: Musica'' (1520, Fossombrone)
====Sacred==== =====Masses===== * ''[[Josquin des Prez]]: Misse [I]'' (1502) * ''[[Jacob Obrecht]]: Misse'' (1503) * ''[[Antoine Brumel]]: Misse'' (1503) * ''[[Johannes Ghiselin]]: Misse'' (1503) * ''[[Pierre de La Rue]]: Misse'' (1503) * ''[[Alexander Agricola]]: Misse'' (1504) * ''[[Marbrianus de Orto]]: Misse'' (1505) * ''Josquin des Prez: Misse II'' (1505) * ''Fragmenta missarum'' (1505) * ''[[Heinrich Isaac]]: Misse'' (1506) * ''[[Gaspar van Weerbeke]]: Misse'' (1507) * ''Missarum diversorum autorum I'' (1508) * ''Messa corale'' (probably 1513, Fossombrone) * ''Josquin des Prez: Misse III'' (1514, Fossombrone) * ''Josquin des Prez: Misse II'' (1515, Fossombrone) * ''[[Jean Mouton]]: Misse I'' (1515, Fossombrone) * ''[[Antoine de Févin]]: Misse'' (1515, Fossombrone) * ''Missarum decem libri duo'' (1515, Fossombrone, lost) * ''Josquin des Prez: Misse I'' (1516, Fossombrone)
=====Motets===== * ''Motetti A'' (1502) * ''Motetti de passione [...] B'' (1503) * ''Motetti C'' (1504) * ''Motetti IV'' (1505) * ''Motetti a cinque I'' (1505) * ''Motetti de la corona [I]'' (1514, Fossombrone) * ''Motetti de la corona II'' (1519, Fossombrone) * ''Motetti de la corona III'' (1519, Fossombrone) * ''Motetti de la corona IV'' (1519, Fossombrone)
=====Other genres===== * ''Lamentationum Jeremie I'' (1506) * ''Lamentationum Jeremie II'' (1506) * ''Magnificats I'' (1507, lost) * ''[[Johannes Martini]]: Hymnorum I'' (1507, lost) * ''Laude II'' (1508) * ''Dammonis: Laude I'' (1508)
===Lute=== * ''[[Francesco Spinacino]]: Intabolatura de lauto I'' (before 27 March 1507) * ''Francesco Spinacino: Intabolatura de lauto II'' (1507) * ''[[Giovanni Maria Alemanni]]: Intabolatura de lauto III'' (1508, lost) * ''[[Joan Ambrosio Dalza]]: Intabolatura de lauto IV'' (1508)
===Non-musical=== * ''[[Paul of Middelburg|Paulus de Middelburgh]]: Paulina de recta Paschae'' (1513, Fossombrone) * ''[[Baldassare Castiglione]]: Epistola de vita'' (1513, Fossombrone) * ''Paulus de Middelburgh: Parabola Christi'' (1516, Fossombrone) * ''[[Hippocrates]], trans. Calvo'' (1519?, Fossombrone)
==References== * Stanley Boorman, ''Ottaviano Petrucci: Catalogue Raissonne'', Oxford, Oxford University Press, 2006. pp. 411–413. {{ISBN|0-19-514207-1}}
[[Category:Lists of books|Petrucci, Ottaviano]]

{{infobox artefact |name = Londesborough Brooch |image =[[File:Londesborough Brooch (BM).JPG|350px]] |image_caption = |material = Silver |size = Diameter 10.6 cm, Length 24.2 cm, Weight 201 grammes |writing = |created = Late 8th Century or early 9th Century AD |period = |place = Ireland |location = [[British Museum]] |id = 1888,0719.101 }} The '''Londesborough Brooch''' is a [[Celts|Celtic]] pseudo-[[penannular brooch]] from Ireland. Dating from the early medieval period, it is a particularly elaborate example of a dress fastener that was produced during Ireland's artistic golden age, when objects such as the [[Tara Brooch]] and [[Ardagh Chalice]] were produced. Since 1888, it has been part of the [[British Museum]]'s collection.[https://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/collection_object_details.aspx?objectId=98321&partId=1&searchText=Londesborough+brooch&page=1 British Museum Collection] ==Description== The brooch and pin were cast in [[silver]], though the metal is heavily debased, and tests show it contains about 65% copper, 34% silver, with traces of lead and gold.Youngs, 93 This might reflect an origin in melted-down late Roman coins. The pieces were thickly [[gilding|gilded]] on the front, and selectively on parts of the back of the head. The pin was cast in two pieces, head and shank, joined with a [[rivet]]. Both head and pin were ornamented with geometric and [[zoomorphic]] patterns and inset with [[amber]] pieces, some now missing. On the back of the head there are two blue glass studs near where the large terminal joins the hoop. There are many small differences between the decoration of the right and left sides of the head, although the overall impression is one of symmetry. Many details of the decoration recall the earlier Tara Brooch and the [[Breadalbane Brooch]] (the latter also in the British Museum). However, unlike most other very elaborate brooches of the type, the Londesborough Brooch lacks any gold [[filigree]] decoration, and aspects of the decoration recall larger pieces of church metal work such as shrines. [[Image:Brit Mus 17sept 016.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Detail of the brooch]] ==Original ownership== The intricate decoration on precious metal and the large size of the brooch suggest it was made for a wealthy patron or religious leader in Ireland in the late eighth or early ninth centuries AD. The pseudo-penannular form is typical of Irish brooches at this period; in a true penannular brooch there is a gap in the centre of the wide terminals ending the hoop through which the pin can pass. In the pseudo-penannular type the terminal sides are joined, here by two narrow bands, making the brooch less efficient as a fastener.Youngs, 89-90 ==Provenance== Little is known about the original circumstances of the brooch's discovery before it became part of [[Albert Denison, 1st Baron Londesborough|Lord Londesborough]]'s collection. The British Museum purchased the brooch in 1888. With the Tara Brooch in [[Dublin]], and the [[Hunterston Brooch]] in [[Edinburgh]], it is considered one of the finest of over 50 highly elaborate Irish Celtic brooches to survive.Youngs, 90 ==Notes== {{Reflist|2}} ==References== *Susan Youngs (ed), ''"The Work of Angels", Masterpieces of Celtic Metalwork, 6th–9th centuries AD'', catalogue #71, 1989, British Museum Press, London, {{ISBN|0-7141-0554-6}} (most of the entry is quoted on the BM page, chopped about) ==Further reading== {{commonscat}} *P. Harbison, The golden age of Irish art (London, Thames and Hudson, 1999) [[Category:Archaeology of Ireland]] [[Category:Individual brooches]] [[Category:Celtic brooches]] [[Category:Medieval European objects in the British Museum]] [[Category:Silver-gilt objects]]

revision.comment: Disambiguating links to [[Mace]] (link changed to [[Ceremonial mace]]) using [[User:Qwertyytrewqqwerty/DisamAssist|DisamAssist]].
revision.text:
[[File:Mill Creek Chert production sites HRoe 2010.jpg|thumb|upright=1.35|Map showing geographical extent of Mississippian stone statues]]
'''Mill Creek chert''' is a type of [[chert]] found in [[Southern Illinois]] and heavily exploited by members of the [[Mississippian culture]] (800 to 1600 CE).<ref name=ILLINOISAGRI/> [[Artifact (archaeology)|Artifacts]] made from this material are found in [[archaeological site]]s throughout the [[American Midwest]] and Southeast. It is named for a village and stream near the quarries, [[Mill Creek, Illinois]] and Mill Creek, a [[tributary]] of the [[Cache River (Illinois)|Cache River]].<ref name=QUARRY/> The chert was used extensively for the production of utilitarian tools such as hoes and spades, and for polished ceremonial objects such as [[bifaces]], spatulate celts and [[Ceremonial mace|maces]].
==History== [[File:Cahokia diorama of flint knapper HRoe 2010.jpg|thumb|Diorama at [[Cahokia]] of flintknapper at work on hoes and bifaces]] ''[[Chert]]'' is a [[siliceous]] (silica) stone, a variety of [[quartz]] similar to [[flint]] but more brittle. It naturally occurs as large, flat, elliptically shaped [[Nodule (geology)|nodules]] in [[Creek bed|creek beds]], and sometimes as hill-top [[Residuum (geology)|residuum]]. The nodules were formed as part of the Ullin limestone formation during the [[Mississippian age|Mississippian geologic period]] (roughly 359 to 318 million years ago). Mill Creek Chert is a tough, coarse-grained chert, usually brown or gray in color, and occurs as large tabular shaped nodules, a shape used by members of the [[Mississippian culture]] for the manufacture of broad bifaces such as [[Hoe (tool)|hoes]], [[spade]]s, and ceremonial maces and spuds.<ref name=ILLINOISAGRI>{{Cite web|url= http://www.museum.state.il.us/exhibits/agriculture/htmls/technology/hand_tools/tech_hand_na.html|title=Illinois Agriculture-Technology-Hand tools-Native American Tools|accessdate =2010-07-12}}</ref><ref name=SIUHISTORY>{{Cite web|url=http://www.southernmostillinoishistory.net/mississippian.htm|title= Mill Creek chert, Millstone Bluff, Kincaid Mounds:900 to 1550 AD|accessdate =2010-07-12}}</ref> At the turn of the 20th century, [[archaeologists]] began realizing that in the hilly lands of [[Southern Illinois]] was the location for the [[quarrying]] and production centers -- one of the greatest in [[Prehistory|prehistoric]] North America for this type of stone.<ref name=QUARRY/> The sites were located near Mill Creek, Illinois, a village in [[Union County, Illinois|Union County]], located between [[Jonesboro, Illinois|Jonesboro]] and [[Cairo, Illinois|Cairo]] on the [[Alexander County, Illinois|Alexander County]] line.<ref name=SIUHISTORY/> From this collection of sites, known colloquially as the "Indian Diggings", [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]] quarried, worked into tools and [[Blank (archaeology)|blanks]], and exported this stone to the wider Mississippian world. The chert found here was one of the major exported raw materials of the Mississippian culture and its distribution and procurement was one of the largest mining and production efforts organized during the Mississippian period.<ref name=QUARRY/> The raw material was dug up in the quarries and then transported to small hamlets for production in hoes, spades and blanks. Archaeologists believe they were then transported to and traded at regional mound centers such as the Hale Site, a [[palisade]]d village with a [[platform mound]] and a [[burial mound]]. From these local sites they were then transported and traded at sites even further afield. These materials were some of the most widely exchanged items during this period,<ref name=QUARRY>{{Cite book|title=From Quarry to Cornfield-The Political Economy of Mississippian Hoe Production|author=Charles R. Cobb|publisher=[[University of Alabama Press]]|year=2000|isbn=0-8173-1050-9|pages=15–18}}</ref> with especially large amounts transported to the [[American Bottom]] region. Examples are numerous at [[Cahokia]], where it was especially prized for hoes and spades,<ref name=ILLINOISAGRI/> but finds have been made in locations as distant as [[Spiro Mounds|Spiro]] and [[Moundville Archaeological Site|Moundville]].
==Types of use== [[File:Mill Creek Chert hoe distribution HRoe 2010.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|A map showing the geographical distribution and frequency of Mill Creek chert finds]] The most common tools made from Mill Creek chert were digging implements. The physical properties of the stone and its ability to absorb repeated use without breaking as often as other stone, made it especially suitable for these types of tools.<ref name=ILLINOISAGRI/> The Mississippian cultures heavy dependence on [[maize]] agriculture and their monumental architecture ([[platform mound]]s, [[moat]]s and embankments) made such tools especially valuable. Three main varieties of Mississippian culture hoes have been found, differentiated by their shape, oval, flared and notched. The oval and flared varieties were hafted to L-shaped wooden handles, such as the one wielded by the [[Birger figurine]]. The notched version was probably hafted as a spade. Another advantageous property of the Mill Creek chert was the large size of the nodules, which meant that the corresponding tools could be large. Some hoes were up to {{convert|60|cm|in}} in length.<ref name=QUARRY2>{{Cite book|title=From Quarry to Cornfield-The Political Economy of Mississippian Hoe Production|author=Charles R. Cobb|publisher=[[University of Alabama Press]]|year=2000|isbn=0-8173-1050-9|pages=48–50}}</ref>
The other main use for the chert was large ceremonial bifaces, spatulate [[Celt (tool)|celts]] and stone maces. These were ritual objects which often display a high degree of craftmanship. Unlike the hoes and other utilitarian tools, the ritual objects were often ground and polished to a high degree of finish.<ref name=QUARRY2/> Many [[Southeastern Ceremonial Complex]] artworks depict figures wielding these ceremonial items, especially the sword shaped ceremonial bifaces and maces. As with the hoes, these artifacts could also be quite large, with some of the swordlike bifaces being up to {{convert|50|cm|in}} in length. These ritual objects have been found throughout the [[American Bottom]], the Lilbourn Site in [[New Madrid County, Missouri]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.csasi.org/2004_october_journal/2004_selected_pictures_from_the_october_journal.htm|title=Central States Archaeological Societies-Selected Pictures from the 2004 October Journal|accessdate =2010-07-17}}</ref> and as far away as [[Spiro Mounds|Spiro]] and [[Gahagan Mounds Site|Gahagan Mounds]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.texasbeyondhistory.net/tejas/ancestors/early.html|title=Early Caddo, A.D. 800-1200|accessdate =2010-07-17}}</ref> [[Caddoan Mississippian culture]] sites in [[Oklahoma]] and [[Louisiana]]. Although the objects are modeled after actual weapons, such as war clubs, archaeologists believe they were too delicate to function as actual weapons and instead functioned as status symbols.<ref name=QUARRY2/>
==Gallery of Mill Creek chert artifacts== <gallery> File:Mill Creek chert hoe and other artifacts Parkin HRoe 01.jpg|Hoe from the [[Parkin Archeological State Park|Parkin Site]] File:Wilson AR Hampson Museum State Park 41 tools.jpg|Hoes from the [[Nodena Site]] File:Mill Creek chert bifaces Spiro HRoe 01.jpg|Ceremonial swordlike bifaces from the Spiro Mounds site File:Spiro ceremonial mace HRoe 2005.jpg|Mississippian culture stone mace from [[Spiro Mounds|Spiro]] File:Birger figurine (1).jpg|[[Mississippian stone statuary|Stone figurine]] wielding a hoe hafted to an L-shaped handle File:S.E.C.C. Hero Twins 4 HRoe 2006.jpg|[[Southeastern Ceremonial Complex|SECC]] design from an engraved shell found at Spiro File:Rogan plate 1 birdman HRoe 2012.jpg|[[Rogan plate]] found at [[Etowah Indian Mounds|Etowah]] File:Castalian_Springs_Eddyville_style_gorget_design.jpg|SECC design from an engraved shell found at [[Castalian Springs Mound Site|Castalian Springs]] </gallery>
==See also== * [[Visual arts by indigenous peoples of the Americas]] * [[List of Mississippian sites]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{commons category|Mississippian culture monolithic axes and ceremonial blades}} {{commons category|Mississippian culture stone tools}} {{Coord|37|20|37.75|N|89|16|12.36|W|display=title}} * [http://www.silvercreekartifacts.net/pages/spade.html Mill Creek Chert Spade found in St. Frances Co, MO] * [https://www.flickr.com/photos/bshieldsnc/4713114102/meta/ Mill Creek Chert found in Moundville, Alabama] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100616132559/http://csasi.org/2004_october_journal/images/page_74_mace.jpg Mill Creek chert ceremonial mace from Lilbourn Site in New Madrid County, Missouri] {{Mississippian and related cultures}} {{Pre-Columbian North America}}

revision.comment: Successfully de-orphaned! Wikiproject Orphanage: [[Wikipedia:ORPHAN|You can help!]]
revision.text:
'''Monsters of Art''' or '''MOA''' (MOAS, MOAZ, VIM [Vandals in motion, Sweden], VIMOA, [[Amok Living Legends|ALL, Norway]], MOALL, VIMOALL, VIMOAS, VIMOAZ) is a [[Danish people|Danish]] [[graffiti]]crew. They are not only known in Denmark, they are also known as one of the biggest and most respected graffiticrews in the world. It was started by the Danish graffiti-artist Mins in the early 1990s.
They are known for their various pieces on the [[s-trains]] in [[Copenhagen]], and their special style of bombing. They have members in countries all over the world, MOA is often seen at the streets of [[New York City]], and some parts of [[Japan]].
==External links== *MOA on Belgian trains « [http://graffiti-art-on-trains.blogspot.com/search/label/Moas Graffiti Art On Trains] ». *https://web.archive.org/web/20090529145552/http://www.alanemmins.com/feature_syndication/graffiti_moa.html *[https://web.archive.org/web/20140914072851/http://www.moasgallery.com/category/moas-crew moasgallery.com Co-established by one of the founding members of the Monsters of Art ‘Graffiti Crew’]
[[Category:Danish art]]
