===[[Middle East]]=== *Al Mahatta, [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://english.wafa.ps/page.aspx?id=GnpTKxa12554573823aGnpTKx|title=Gallery Al-Mahatta: Manifestation of Complicity with Self|website=وكالة الأنباء والمعلومات الفلسطينية - وفا|access-date=2018-08-19}}</ref> *Batroun Projects, [[Lebanon]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.98weeks.net/p/98events.html|title=WORKSHOPS AND EVENTS|website=www.98weeks.net|access-date=2018-08-19}}</ref> *Wasla Workshop, [[Egypt]]<ref name="remix" /> *Open Studio Project [[Cairo, Egypt]]<ref name="openstudiocairo">{{cite web|url=http://www.openstudiocairo.com/files/opensound/OSP%20overview.pdf |date=27 April 2006 |title=Open Studio Project 2006 |author=Townhouse Gallery |accessdate=20 August 2015 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060824092834/http://www.openstudiocairo.com/files/opensound/OSP%20overview.pdf |archivedate=August 24, 2006 }}</ref> *[[Rybon Art Center]], [[Tehran]], [[Iran]]
===[[Africa]]=== *32° East, [[Uganda]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.arterialnetwork.org/opportunity/32deg|title=Programme Manager, 32° East {{!}} Ugandan Arts Trust|access-date=2018-08-19|language=en}}</ref> *ABRO International Workshop, [[Addis Ababa, Ethiopia]] <ref>http://ethiopia.africancolours.net/content/16381</ref> *Aftershave workshop, [[Nigeria]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aftershaveworkshop.org/|title=芸術的なワークショップ情報局|work=aftershaveworkshop.org|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref> *Bag Factory, [[Johannesburg, South Africa|Johannesburg]]<ref name=remix /> *Batapata workshop, [[Zimbabwe]]<ref name=remix /> *Greatmore Studios, [[Cape Town, South Africa|Cape Town]]<ref name=remix /> *Kuona Trust & Wasanii workshop, [[Kenya]]<ref>http://www.kuonatrust.org/LinkClick.aspx?fileticket=L1T%2Fa7vb1Zo%3D&tabid=100&mid=426</ref> *Mbile/Insaka workshops, [[Zambia]] *Ngoma workshop, [[Uganda]]<ref name=remix /> *Njelele, [[Zimbabwe]] *Pachipamwe workshop, [[Zimbabwe]]<ref name="remix" /> *Partage, [[Mauritius]] *Rafiki workshop, [[Tanzania]]<ref name=remix /> *Rockston Studios, [[Zambia]]<ref name=remix /> *Tenq workshop, [[Senegal]]<ref name=remix /> *Thapong workshop, [[Botswana]]<ref name=remix /> *Thupelo workshop, Cape Town and [[Johannesburg, South Africa|Johannesburg]] <ref name=remix /> *[[Tulipamwe]] workshop, [[Namibia]]<ref name=remix /> *Ujamaa workshop, [[Mozambique]]
===[[Asia]] and [[Australia]]=== *112A residency, [[China]] *[[Britto Arts Trust]], [[Bangladesh]]<ref name=KHOJ>{{cite web|url=http://khojworkshop.org/book/south_asian_network_for_the_arts_sana|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070823065407/http://khojworkshop.org/book/south_asian_network_for_the_arts_sana|archive-date=2007-08-23|dead-url=yes|title=Books | Khoj International Artists' Association|accessdate=20 August 2015|df=}}</ref> *Burragorang workshop, [[Australia]] *Cona Foundation, [[India]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://artradarjournal.com/2014/06/13/4-contemporary-art-initiatives-in-mumbai/|title=4 contemporary art initiatives in Mumbai {{!}} Art Radar|website=artradarjournal.com|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-08-19}}</ref> *Flats workshop, [[Australia]] *[[Hong Kong]] International Artists' Workshop *KHOJ, [[India]]<ref name="KHOJ" /> *Kimberley workshop, [[Australia]] *Lijiang workshop, [[China]] *No.1 Shanthi Road, [[India]] *Organhaus, [[China]] *Sutra workshop & residency, [[Nepal]]<ref name="KHOJ" /> *Theertha, [[Sri Lanka]]<ref name="KHOJ" /> *Upriver Loft residency, [[China]] *Vasl workshop & residency, [[Pakistan]]<ref name="KHOJ" /><ref name="universes-in-universe">{{cite web|url=http://universes-in-universe.org/nafas/articles/2007/taza_tareen_ii|title=Fresh Cream, Again. Nafas Art Magazine|publisher=universes-in-universe.org|accessdate=20 August 2015}}</ref> *Village workshop, [[Rajasthan, India|Rajasthan]]

revision.text:
{{Redirect|Kolkhoznitsa|the Russian word denoting a female collective-farm worker|Kolkhoz}} {{Infobox artwork | image_file = [[File:The_Worker_and_Kolkhoz_Woman.jpg|250px]] | image_size = 50px | title = Worker and Kolkhoz Woman | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = Рабо́чий и колхо́зница (Rabochiy i Kolkhoznitsa) | artist = [[Vera Mukhina]] | year = 1937 | type = [[Stainless steel]] | height_metric = 24.5 | metric_unit = m | imperial_unit = ft | city = [[All-Russian Exhibition Centre|Russian Exhibition Centre]], [[Moscow]] | museum = }} '''''Worker and Kolkhoz Woman''''' ({{lang-ru|Рабо́чий и колхо́зница}} ''Rabochiy i Kolkhoznitsa'') is a sculpture of two figures with a [[Hammer and sickle|sickle and a hammer]] raised over their heads. It is 24.5 meters (78 feet) high, made from [[stainless steel]] by [[Vera Mukhina]] for the [[Exposition Internationale des Arts et Techniques dans la Vie Moderne (1937)|1937 World's Fair]] in [[Paris]],<ref name="overy260">[[Richard Overy]], ''The Dictators: Hitler's Germany, Stalin's Russia'', p260 {{ISBN|0-393-02030-4}}</ref> and subsequently moved to [[Moscow]]. The sculpture is an example of the [[socialist realism|socialist realistic]] style, as well as [[Art Deco]] style. The worker holds aloft a hammer and the [[kolkhoz]] woman a sickle to form the [[hammer and sickle]] symbol.<ref name="overy260"/>
==History== [[File:Paris-expo-1937-pavillon de l'URSS-13.jpg|thumb|upright|1937 Expo pavilion in Paris]] The sculpture was originally created to crown the Soviet pavilion of the World's Fair.<ref name="overy260"/> The organizers had placed the Soviet and German pavilions facing each other across the main pedestrian boulevard at the [[Trocadéro]] on the north bank of the Seine.<ref name="overy260"/>
Mukhina was inspired by her study of the classical ''[[Harmodius and Aristogeiton (sculpture)|Harmodius and Aristogeiton]]'', the ''[[Victory of Samothrace]]'' and ''[[La Marseillaise]]'', [[François Rude]]'s sculptural group for the [[Arc de Triomphe]],<ref name="Power 1995">''Art and Power: Europe under the dictators'', 1995, {{ISBN|1-85332-148-6}}</ref> to bring a monumental composition of socialist realist confidence to the heart of Paris. The symbolism of the two figures striding from West to East, as determined by the layout of the pavilion, was also not lost on the spectators.<ref name="ReferenceA">''Totalitarian Art'', Golomstock, 1990 {{ISBN|0-00-272169-4}}</ref>
Mukhina said that her sculpture was intended "to continue the idea inherent in the building, and this sculpture was to be an inseparable part of the whole structure",<ref>''Arkhitekturnaya gazeta'', 28 February 1938</ref> but after the fair, the ''Rabochiy i Kolkhoznitsa'' was relocated to [[Moscow]] where it was placed just outside the [[All-Russia Exhibition Centre]].
In 1941, the sculpture earned Mukhina one of the initial batch of [[Stalin Prize]]s.<ref name="ReferenceA" />
The sculpture was removed for restoration in autumn of 2003 in preparation for [[Expo 2010]]. The original plan was for it to return in 2005, but because the [[World's Fair]] was not awarded to [[Moscow]] but to [[Shanghai]], the restoration process was hampered by financial problems and re-installation was delayed. See photographs of the disassembled statue.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20080427093215/http://community.livejournal.com/ru_sovarch/175556.html webarchive community.livejournal.com]</ref>
It finally returned to its place at [[All-Russia Exhibition Centre|VDNKh]] on November 28, 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.rian.ru/russia/20091128/157018323.html |title=Moscow reinstalls landmark Soviet statue | Russia | RIA Novosti |publisher=En.rian.ru |date=2009-11-28 |accessdate=2012-08-15}}</ref> The revealing of the restored monument was held on the evening of December 4, 2009, accompanied by fireworks.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://rt.com/Art_and_Fun/2009-12-04/second-life-socialist-monument.html |title=Second life of great Socialist monument — RT |publisher=Rt.com |date= |accessdate=2012-08-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091213020355/http://rt.com/Art_and_Fun/2009-12-04/second-life-socialist-monument.html |archivedate=2009-12-13 |df= }}</ref> The restored statue uses a new pavilion as its pedestal, increasing its total height from 34.5 meters (the old pedestal was 10 meters tall) to 60 meters (the new pavilion is 34.5 meters tall plus 24.5 meters of the statue's own height).<ref>{{cite web | title = "Рабочий и колхозница". Сложная судьба эталона соцреализма | publisher = РИА НОВОСТИ | date = 2007-04-11 | url = http://www.rian.ru/spravka/20070411/63472592.html | accessdate = 2007-08-09 }}</ref>
==Use in media== In Soviet cinema, the sculpture was chosen in 1947 to serve as the logo<ref>http://www.ytfiles.com/2009/12/10/worker-and-kolkhoz-woman-a-soviet-era-monument-finds-its-way-back-into-moscows-landscape/</ref> for the [[film studio]] [[Mosfilm]]. It can be seen in the opening credits of the film ''[[Red Heat (1988 film)|Red Heat]]'', as well as many of the Russian films released by the [[Mosfilm]] studio itself.
A giant moving reproduction of the statue was featured in the [[2014 Winter Olympics opening ceremony|opening ceremony]] of the [[2014 Winter Olympics|2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia]],<ref>{{cite news|title = Olympics Opening Ceremony Offers Fanfare for a Reinvented Russia| work = The New York Times| date = 7 February 2014| url = https://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/08/sports/olympics/russia-opens-sochi-games-with-pageantry-and-pride.html?_r=0| accessdate = 2009-02-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| title = Sochi 2014 in five pictures| work = beranger.org| date = 7 February 2014| url = http://beranger.org/2014/02/07/sochi-2014-in-five-pictures/| accessdate = 2009-02-09| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://archive.is/20140209212605/http://beranger.org/2014/02/07/sochi-2014-in-five-pictures/| archivedate = 9 February 2014| df = }}</ref> symbolizing post-World War II Soviet society, particularly in Moscow.
==Gallery== <gallery perrow=3 widths="240px" heights="200px"> File:Russia-2000-stamp-Tatlin Tower and Worker and Kolkhoz Woman by Vera Mukhina.jpg|''Worker and Kolkhoz Woman'' was among achievements of the 20th century in the arts to be commemorated in Russian stamps in 2000 (depicted with [[Tatlin's Tower]]) </gallery>
==See also== {{wikinews|Soviet statue returns to Moscow}} *[[Socialist realism]] *[[List of statues by height]]
